title: Climate change caused mass extinction apocalypse & killed 75% of life on Earth
text:
It’s feared humanity will cause the next mass extinction (Picture: Nasa)

A mass extinction which wiped out three our four species on Earth was caused by cataclysmic climate change.

That’s the finding in a new piece of research which warns that humanity’s pollution could be having the same effects as natural processes which caused the disaster.

The ancient apocalypse took place 201 million years ago and was believed to have been caused by volcanoes which spewed greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and caused runaway global warming.

But an international research team led by the Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland (GEUS) has analysed data from ancient fern spores and find that increased concentrations of the toxic element mercury in the environment contributed to the mass extinction.

‘These ferns were negatively affected by the mercury levels,’ said lead scientist Sofie Lindström.

‘Since mercury is accumulated in the food chain, it seems likely that other species have suffered as well.

‘These results suggest that the end-Triassic mass extinction was not just caused by greenhouse gases from volcanoes causing global climate change, but that they also emitted toxins such as mercury – wreaking havoc.’

Co-author Professor Hamed Sanei from Aarhus University has previously showed that volcanos churned out mercury a severe mass extinction called the end-Permian crisis, when up to 95% of life on Earth disappeared. It’s believed that volcanic activity is responsible for roughly four of the five largest mass extinctions during the last 500 million years.

‘Prior to industrialism, volcanic activity was the major release mechanism of large amounts of mercury from the Earth’s crust,’ Sanei said.

‘That makes it possible to use mercury in sediments to trace major volcanic activity in the Earth’s past.’

Will humans cause another mass extinction? (Picture: Getty)

The team found that mutated mercury spores became more common as mercury levels increased.

‘In some of my counts I found almost only mutated spores and no normal ones, which is very unusual,’ Sofie Lindström added.

It’s believed soaring mercury levels caused mass poisoning and therefore ‘help to explain the sudden deterioration of the ecosystem’.

“This could hint to that the whole food chain might have been negatively affected,’ Lindström added.

‘Generally, we prefer simple explanations to mass extinctions such as meteorite impacts or climate change, but I don’t think it’s that simple.

‘As our study suggests there could very well be a cocktail effect of CO2 and global warming, toxins like mercury, and other factors as well.’

‘Still, it is very difficult to say how big the importance of one factor is because mass extinctions like this are very likely very complex events. Our study shows that mercury affected the ferns and likely also other plants, and it may also have had an impact on the entire food chain.’

The researchers claimed their study of the end-Triassic mass extinction ‘in many ways draws parallels to the current global situation’.

‘Our global society emits a lot of the same substances and greenhouse gases as these huge volcanic provinces did during these mass extinctions. Therefore, studies in what happened back then might help us to prevent it from happening again,’ Lindström concluded.
description: And human pollution could have a similar effect to lethal natural processes which caused the ancient cataclysm.
